Dave,
thanks for your help.  I will tell you how its goes.
Dave 

>>> dgoodwin@... 6/16/2004 6:17:57 PM >>>
Dave,

It turned out to be easy to fix.  I had already implemented everything

needed, except that the reaction orders specified in the input file 
were being ignored when building the mechanism object.  It is now 
fixed, and I have tested it to verify that it is working, using the 
attached cti file and python script. The CVS repository is now updated;

do you need it in any other form? I have not yet looked at adding 
'FORD' to ck2cti.

For your mechanism,  set the stoichiometric coefficients so they are 
all integers.  Then divide the A parameter by whatever factor (e.g. 2)

you multiplied the stoichiometric coefficients by, and specify the 
reaction orders for all reactants.  If you do this, Cantera and Chemkin

should give the same results for these reactions with non-integral 
orders.

Note that Cantera allows specifying reaction orders ONLY for 
irreversible reactions, so you will need to split your second reaction

into 2 irreversible reactions first.  It is definitely not correct 
thermodynamically to compute reverse rate coefficients from microscopic

reversibility if the reaction orders differ from the stoichiometric 
coefficients.  This only works if the kinetic rate law has the same 
functional form as the equilibrium constant - i.e. mass-action 
kinetics.  I don't know why Chemkin allows this - it can lead to 
subtle, hard-to-catch internal inconsistencies.  If you do specify a 
Chemkin reaction this way, you will find that the net rate of progress

is not zero in states of chemical equilibrium; and therefore 
microscopic reversibility is violated.  To help you stay on the right 
side of the Laws of Thermodynamics, Cantera only allows reversible 
reactions to have mass-action kinetics.

Let me know if you encounter any problems.

Dave



On Jun 16, 2004, at 1:54 PM, E David Huckaby wrote:

> Dave,
>
> Thanks for your help.
>
> I have attached a few version of the mechanism
> in various file formats.
>
> Dave H.
>
>>>> dgoodwin@... 6/16/2004 3:16:59 PM >>>
> Dave,
>
> Non-integer reaction orders are currently supported for surface
> reaction mechanisms, but not for homogeneous mechanisms.  There is
no
> particular difficulty in doing it for homogeneous mechanisms.  I
will
> make the appropriate modifications later today and update the CVS
> repository.  I also see that the input file documentation doesn't
even
>
> mention specifying reaction orders, so I'll bring it up to date too
> soon.
>
> As for the specific points you mention:
>
> 1) ck2cti doesn't support FORD and RORD;  I'll see if I can easily
> implement it.
>
> 2) you're right - currently it will read the reaction orders but
ignore
>
> them for a homogeneous mechanism.
>
> 3) Non-unity stoichiometric coefficients should work fine, but this
is
>
> different than specifying reaction orders that do not equal the
> stoichiometric coefficients. If you have a mechanism file where this
is
>
> not working correctly, please send it to me.
>
>
> Dave
>
>
>
> On Jun 16, 2004, at 11:23 AM, E David Huckaby wrote:
>
>> Hello,
>>
>> Is there a way to introduce arbitrary reaction orders into the
>> kinetic rate expressions ?
>>
>> I tried the following:
>>
>> 1) using the FORD, RORD auxillary keywords in a chemkin input file
> and
>> using
>> ck2cti to convert the reactions.   ck2cti parses the chemkin input
> file
>> but does
>> not make in modifications to the description of the reaction in the
>> .cti file
>>
>> 2) manually modify the reaction section of the .cti with the
"order"
>> keyword.  This
>> is read into the Cantera succsesfully but the reaction rate values
> are
>> to small.
>>
>> I also tried specifying a reaction with non-unity stoichmetric
>> coefficients:
>> 2 [A] + 3 [B] -> 1 [C] + 4 [D]
>> which also seemed to foul up the reaction rate calculations.
>>
>> Also using non integer stoichmetric coefficients in a chemkin input
>> file
>> or .cti file is flag as invalid by approriate Cantera utility.
>>
>> Any suggestions ?
>>
>> thanks
>>
>> Dave Huckaby
>>
>>
